title: How to Make Green Bean Pickles (Cold Pack)

steps.headline: Prepare your work area.
steps.description: Lay out the "Things You'll Need" listed below, along with all ingredients, in a clean kitchen area.

steps.headline: Cut the ends off the beans.
steps.description: Cutting them to the length of the canning jar makes it easier to pack the jars later.

steps.headline: Set the washed and cut beans aside.
Set your boiling water canner on the stove and get your water boiling.
Sterilize the jars you intend to use in a boiling water bath for around 10 minutes.
While the canner is heating up, mix your vinegar, water and salt together in a separate pan.
steps.description: Add two cloves of peeled and sliced garlic to them and bring them to a boil until all the salt is dissolved.

steps.headline: Remove the pint jars from the boiling water bath.
Place a sprig of dill and any pepper into the bottom of the jar.
Pack the jar full of beans, leaving a half inch of "headroom".
Ladle the hot vinegar/water/salt mixture over the beans until they are covered.
steps.description: Leave a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of "headroom" in the jar. Note: you may place one of the garlic slices in the top of the jar for a heavier garlic flavor to your pickles if you prefer.

steps.headline: Place a lid on the jar and snug it down with the ring.
When you have completed packing all the jars and topping them off with the vinegar mixture, place all the jars on the rack and return the rack to the boiling water in the canner.
Boil the jars in the hot water bath at a simmer (not a rolling boil) for 5 minutes for crisp pickles, longer for softer pickles.
Remove the jars from the water and allow them to cool on the rack or on a towel placed on the counter top.
Allow 3 days for the vinegar mixture to thoroughly penetrate the beans before opening for consumption.

text: Prepare your work area. Lay out the "Things You'll Need" listed below, along with all ingredients, in a clean kitchen area. Wash the beans.  Cut the ends off the beans. Cutting them to the length of the canning jar makes it easier to pack the jars later. Set the washed and cut beans aside.  Set your boiling water canner on the stove and get your water boiling.  Sterilize the jars you intend to use in a boiling water bath for around 10 minutes.  While the canner is heating up, mix your vinegar, water and salt together in a separate pan. Add two cloves of peeled and sliced garlic to them and bring them to a boil until all the salt is dissolved. Remove the pint jars from the boiling water bath. (carefully!) Place a sprig of dill and any pepper into the bottom of the jar.  Pack the jar full of beans, leaving a half inch of "headroom".  Ladle the hot vinegar/water/salt mixture over the beans until they are covered. Leave a ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) of "headroom" in the jar. Note: you may place one of the garlic slices in the top of the jar for a heavier garlic flavor to your pickles if you prefer. Place a lid on the jar and snug it down with the ring.  Place on the canning rack.  When you have completed packing all the jars and topping them off with the vinegar mixture, place all the jars on the rack and return the rack to the boiling water in the canner.  Boil the jars in the hot water bath at a simmer (not a rolling boil) for 5 minutes for crisp pickles, longer for softer pickles.  Remove the jars from the water and allow them to cool on the rack or on a towel placed on the counter top.  Allow 3 days for the vinegar mixture to thoroughly penetrate the beans before opening for consumption.
